qas.question: What portion of music sales did CDs and DVDs account for in the United States as of 2012?
Which country attributes over 80 percent of its music sales to physical formats?
When did CD sales experience their original decline?
What has caused a decrease in CD sales?
In what year did CDs have an unusual spike in sales?
What percentage of music sales do MP3s make up?
By what percentage have DIY and independent CDs increased?
When did MP3 sales take off in Japan?

context: Meanwhile, with the advent and popularity of <a4_0>Internet-based distribution of files<a4_0/> in <a2_0><b7_0>lossily-compressed<b7_0/><a2_0/> audio formats such as MP3, sales of CDs began to decline in the <a3_0>2000s<a3_0/>. For example, between 2000 - <b5_0>2008<b5_0/>, despite overall growth in music sales and one anomalous year of increase, major-label CD sales declined overall by <b8_0>20%<b8_0/>, although independent and DIY music sales may be tracking better according to figures released 30 March 2009, and CDs still continue to sell greatly. As of 2012, CDs and DVDs made up only <a0_0><b6_0>34<b6_0/> percent<a0_0/> of music sales in the United States. In <a1_0>Japan<a1_0/>, however, over 80 percent of music was bought on CDs and other physical formats as of <b9_0>2015<b9_0/>.
